question.title: Spring boot with Jersey and spring mvc: register services to ResourceConfig
question.body:
I've read a lot of post/examples that explain how to create the JerseyConfig bean extending the ResourceConfig class: all of them say that I need to register in JerseyConfig constructor all the resources I need it to map.

Here is an example:

@Configuration
@ApplicationPath(“/resource”)
public class JerseyConfig extends ResourceConfig {

   public JerseyConfig() {
      register(HelloWorld.class);
      property(ServletProperties.FILTER_FORWARD_ON_404, true);
   }
}

I'm working on a complex maven project made of tons of modules and the resulting application is built using profiles depending on the customer. So depending on the profile I may or may not have one or more resources in the final application.

Is there a way to avoid the explicit registration of each resource? Or is there a more flexible way of doing it?

question_comments.body: Using the package gives a little more flexibility, but non the less you need to know in advance what you'll have in the application. We are trying to use both jax-rs and spring mvc because it seems that jax-rs handles better the use of the output stream as response to a rest call, while spring mvc stores all in memory before sending data over the output stream
I'm not a jersey user, but their documentation shows the usage of a package method on example 4.2, is that what you need? Also if you don't mind me asking, why use jax-rs AND spring-boot?
